results.title: Belgium and the Netherlands
results.brief_description: A survey of Belgium and the Netherlands, their relationship to each other and to their neighbours. Explains how their culture and economy are affected by environmental factors such as easy access to the North Sea, their small size and dense population and their coal resources. No other credits available.

results.title: Belgium
results.creator_credit: Boulton-Hawker Films and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids
results.brief_description: A skipper of a barge who travels the canals and rivers of Belgium tells about Belgium, describing its role as a historic invasion route since the days of Caesar. Discusses the country’s bi-lingual system, contrasts the fertile Flanders with the industrial south, and shows the importance of Antwerp as a European harbour.

results.title: The Belgian begonia
results.creator_credit: Genevieve Grandry and Belgian Ministry of Agriculture
results.brief_description: The cultivation of begonia tubers at Ghent for export showing the care with which they are planted and tended. Shows the flowers in colourful profusion in gardens, parks, and homes.

results.title: Being real about relationships
results.brief_description: In the second half of the Twentieth Century there have been developments in contraception. The film explains the rhythm, the calender, the temperature, the ovulation, the withdrawal, the barrier, the diaphragm, the condom, the IUD, the pill and the sterilisation methods.

results.title: Being different
results.creator_credit: Julia Murphy, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “What Do You Think”.
Departing from the norm, from accepting patterns of dress or behaviour, can bring down on the head of an erring teenager the unqualified disapproval of his gang. Is this attitude valid? The film cites the case of a thirteen year old boy who has developed an interest in collecting butterflies - a hobby that his friends laugh at. Should he pursue his genuine interest, or should he conform?

results.title: Behind the switch
results.creator_credit: Neil Howe, Shan Benson and State Electricity Commission of Victoria
results.brief_description: Every switch is a demand for instant electricity. Shows how this demand is met in Victoria. The Latrobe Valley brown coal provides four-fifths of electricity. Shows work at Yallourn and Morwell and progress on the new Hazelwood power station. Use of electricity in industry, at home, for transport, and entertainment. Increasing demands are a measure of the State’s growth and rate of development. Emphasis on ability to meet future demands.

results.title: Behind the skyscrapers
results.creator_credit: Frederick Niemann, National Women's Christian Temperance Union and White Ribbon
results.brief_description: Documentary of life on “Skid Row”, a section of a metropolitan city, where down and out people live in doorways and in condemned housing. Factual, unrehearsed scenes show us their lives.

results.title: Behind the menu
results.brief_description: A warning against unsanitary conditions in restaurants, and a demonstration of precautions that should be taken against dirt and harmful bacteria in the handling of food. Suggestions are made for increasing efficiency through better food storage, dishwashing methods and staff facilities. Measures taken by public health authorities to maintain standards in restaurants.

results.title: Behind the flyways
results.creator_credit: Rex Gary Schmidt and United States. Fisheries and Wildlife Service
results.brief_description: This film illustrates how data is gathered on the North American continent for use in making water-fowl regulations. Depicts all types of water-fowl hunting. Shows biologists and other personnel making field studies from Mexico to the Arctic on land, water and in the air. Explains how the information obtained is used in developing regulations.
